prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
################################## # IRAS 08572+3915 HCN/HCO+ J=3-2 # ##################################
Basic observing parameters: For our molecular line observations of all sources, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA) (C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6), to pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas at galaxy nuclei (<1 arcsec in size). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values. We set the detection significance of >5 for the peak flux of the target HCN molecular lines of all sources, in the 20 km/s velocity resolution spectra. Since at least several consecutive pixels should show significant flux excess (>200 km/s line width vs 20 km/s velocity resolution), the final detection significance of the target HCN molecular line, based on Gaussian fit and/or moment 0 map, will be >10.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: Three buried-AGN-dominated ULIRGs (IRAS 08572+3915, 12127-1412, 00183-7111) were observed with our ALMA Cycle 0 program (2011.0.00020.S). IRAS 08572+3915 shows the brightest HCN J=4-3 and HCO+ J=4-3 fluxes (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013c). We thus propose to conduct further observations of IRAS 08572+3915 to better understand molecular line flux ratios from a buried AGN and their physical origin, with high S/N ratios.
Based on our ALMA Cycle 0 data, the HCN J=4-3 peak flux of IRAS 08572+3915 is estimated to be 10 mJy (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013c). When HCN is thermally-excited at up to J=4-3, the HCN J=3-2 peak flux is 9/16 of the HCN J=4-3 peak flux (i.e., 5.5 mJy). When HCN J=4-3 is sub-thermally excited, the HCN J=3-2 peak flux is larger than 9/16 of the HCN J=4-3 peak flux.
On the other hand, it is known that HCN J=1-0 and infrared (8-1000 micron) luminosity (flux) correlate well for Galactic and extra-galactic dusty active regions (Gao & Solomon 2004; Wu et al. 2005). Based on our pre-ALMA interferometric data, we also found the correlation between HCN J=1-0 peak flux from ULIRG's nuclei and galaxy-wide infrared flux measured with IRAS's large aperture (Figure 3). This correlation again supports the scenario that ULIRG's dominant energy sources are located in nuclear regions. We can convert the IRAS-measured infrared (8-1000 micron) flux to the HCN J=1-0 emission peak flux, using the dashed line in Figure 3. If we assume thermal excitation of HCN at up to J=4-3, then the expected HCN J=4-3 emission peak flux is about 50 mJy in IRAS 08572+3915. The observed HCN J=4-3 peak flux of 10 mJy is only 1/5 of the expected flux for thermal excitation, suggesting that the HCN emission is only subthermally-excited at J=4-3. Thus, we can safely adopt >5.5 mJy as the HCN J=3-2 peak flux of IRAS 08572+3915.
We set the required 1 sigma noise level to be 1.0 mJy so that we can detect the peak flux with >5 sigma, even in the most pessimistic case (5.5 mJy).
Since the primary aim of this proposal is to compare the flux ratios among HCN, HCO+, and HNC, we need data of HCO+ J=3-2 and HNC J=3-2. Using ALMA, we can observe HCN J=3-2 and HCO+ J=3-2 simultaneously. At J=4-3, the HCN-to-HCO+ flux ratio in IRAS 08572+3915 is 0.8 (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013c). With the 1.0 mJy noise level, we can distinguish clearly whether the HCN-to HCO+ flux ratio at J=3-2 is similar to or larger than 0.8. The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that 0.7 hr is needed to achieve the 1.0 mJy noise level with the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use three spectral windows in USB to cover HCN J=3-2, HCO+ J=3-2 + HCN v2=1f J=3-2, and HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time. This is the reason for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

################################################## # IRAS 19254-7245 (Superantennae) HCN/HCO+ J=3-2 # ##################################################
Basic observing parameters: For our molecular line observations of all sources, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA) (C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6), to pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas emission at galaxy nuclei (<1 arcsec in size). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values. We set the detection significance of >5 for the peak flux of the target HCN molecular lines of all sources, in the 20 km/s velocity resolution spectra.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: IRAS 19254-7245 (Superantennae) is selected as a buried-AGN significant ULIRG (Imanishi et al. 2010). The energetic contribution from a buried AGN to the total energy budget in Superantennae is estimated to be 30-50% (Imanishi et al. 2010). It is important to confirm if the molecular line flux ratios of this buried AGN significant source is distributed between buried AGN dominated sources and starburst dominated sources.
We estimate the expected HCN J=1-0 flux from the IRAS-measured infrared flux (Figure 3, dashed line). Assuming thermal excitation, the expected HCN J=3-2 peak flux is 30 mJy for Superantennae. Our ALMA Cycle 0 observations show that HCN J=4-3 emission is often only sub-thermally excited even in active ULIRGs hosting luminous buried AGNs (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013c). We thus consider the case that the HCN J=3-2 peak flux is only 1/5 of the expected value for thermal excitation. This assumption is conservative, because excitation at J=3-2 should be closer to thermal than at J=4-3. Namely, the expected HCN J=3-2 peak flux of Superantennae is 6-30 mJy.
The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.6 hr observing time, 1.0 mJy noise level is achieved, with the 20 km/s velocity resolution. With this noise level, we should be able to detect the HCN J=3-2 peak flux with >5 sigma, even in the most pessimistic case (6 mJy).
HCO+ J=3-2 line is simultaneously observable with HCN J=3-2 line.
In ALMA Cycle 0, we observed IRAS 20551-4250 (z=0.043) as an example of AGN-significant ULIRG, with 30-50% buried AGN contribution to the total energy budget. IRAS 20551-4250 shows very small molecular line widths and the vibrationally-excited (v2=1f) HCN J=4-3 emission line was detected (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013b). We thus propose detailed observations of IRAS 20551-4250 to understand the role of an infrared radiative pumping mechanism (third possible scenario for the HCN flux enhancement in AGNs mentioned in the scientific justification of this proposal) in a separate proposal.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use three spectral windows in USB to cover HCN J=3-2, HCO+ J=3-2 + HCN v2=1f J=3-2, and HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time. This is the reason for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

################################## # IRAS 12112+0305 HCN/HCO+ J=3-2 # ##################################
Basic observing parameters: For our molecular line observations of all sources, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA) (C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6), to pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas emission at galaxy nuclei (<1 arcsec in size). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values. We set the detection significance of >5 for the peak flux of the target HCN molecular lines of all sources, in the 20 km/s velocity resolution spectra.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: IRAS 12112+0305 is classified as starburst-dominated, with no detectable AGN activity, based on infrared 2.5-30 micron spectroscopy (Imanishi et al. 2007; 2010; Veilleux et al. 2010; Nardini et al. 2010). Among many such starburst-classified ULIRGs through infrared 2.5-30 micron spectroscopy, we select IRAS 12112+0305, because (1) it shows the highest infrared flux (and thereby highest expected HCN J=1-0 peak flux), and (2) its declination is +03 degree, which is best observable from the ALMA site in Chile.
We convert the IRAS-measured infrared flux to HCN J=1-0 peak flux. Assuming thermal excitation, the expected HCN J=3-2 peak flux is 40 mJy for IRAS 12112+0305. We also consider the case that HCN J=3-2 peak flux is only 1/5 of the expected value for thermal excitation. We adopt 8-40 mJy as the HCN J=3-2 peak flux of IRAS 12112+0305.
The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.5 hr observing time, 1.5 mJy noise level is achieved, with the 20 km/s velocity resolution. HCN J=3-2 peak flux should be detected with >5 sigma, even in the most pessimistic case (8 mJy).
HCO+ J=3-2 line is simultaneously observable with HCN J=3-2 line.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use three spectral windows in USB to cover HCN J=3-2, HCO+ J=3-2 + HCN v2=1f J=3-2, and HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time. This is the reason for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

################################## # IRAS 22491-1808 HCN/HCO+ J=3-2 # ##################################
Basic observing parameters: For our molecular line observations of all sources, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA) (C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6), to pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas emission at galaxy nuclei (<1 arcsec in size). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values. We set the detection significance of >5 for the peak flux of the target HCN molecular lines of all sources, in the 20 km/s velocity resolution spectra.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: IRAS 22491-1808 was observed in our ALMA Cycle 0 program. Our ALMA Cycle 0 data show that IRAS 22491-1808 has remarkably large turbulent motion with molecular line widths of >400 km/s in FWHM (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013c). HCN J=4-3 flux is higher than we expected for a starburst-dominated galaxy (Figure 2). We propose to observe IRAS 22491-1808 to investigate how a galaxy-wide turbulence heating mechanism (Pan & Padoan 2009) can modify the molecular line flux ratios, in addition to the primary energy sources of ULIRGs (AGN or starburst). Since such galaxy-wide turbulence heating could happen in a non-negligible number of merger-induced ULIRGs, molecular line data of IRAS 22491-1808 are very important.
The HCN J=4-3 peak flux of IRAS 22491-1808 is measured to be 20 mJy, based on our ALMA Cycle 0 data (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013c). We thus obtain a conservative lower limit of the HCN J=3-2 peak flux of 11 mJy, in the case of thermal excitation. The measured HCN J=4-3 peak flux is 1/2 of the expected value based on the conversion from IRAS-measured infrared flux to HCN J=1-0 peak flux, and on the assumption of thermal excitation. Thus, HCN J=4-3 emission is subthermally-excited in IRAS 22491-1808, and so the HCN J=3-2 peak flux must be >11 mJy.
The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.5 hr observing time, we can achieve 2.0 mJy noise level for the 20 km/s velocity resolution. Even in the most pessimistic case (11 mJy), the HCN J=3-2 emission peak flux should be detected with >5 sigma.
HCO+ J=3-2 line is simultaneously observable with HCN J=3-2 line.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use three spectral windows in USB to cover HCN J=3-2, HCO+ J=3-2 + HCN v2=1f J=3-2, and HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time. This is the reason for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

############################################# # NGC 1614 (IRAS 04315-0840) HCN/HCO+ J=3-2 # #############################################
Basic observing parameters: For our molecular line observations of all sources, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA) (C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6), to pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas emission at galaxy nuclei (<1 arcsec in size). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values. We set the detection significance of >5 for the peak flux of the target HCN molecular lines of all sources, in the 20 km/s velocity resolution spectra.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: NGC 1614 is a compact (<2 arcsec) starburst dominated galaxy with infrared luminosity lower than those of ULIRGs (Table 1).
We propose to include both IRAS 12112+0305 (starburst-dominated ULIRG) and NGC 1614 (starburst-dominated less infrared luminous galaxy), to see the variation of molecular line flux ratios at J=4-3 and 3-2, depending on galaxy infrared luminosity. This is because starburst activity per unit volume may be more intense in ULIRGs than in less infrared luminous galaxies, and so excitation conditions might be different, possibly affecting the observed molecular line flux ratios at J=4-3 and 3-2. This information is very important, because (1) it is very likely that many starburst galaxies, mostly less infrared luminous than ULIRGs, will be observed with ALMA in various programs, and because (2) molecular line flux ratios of such starburst galaxies, in addition to starburst-dominated ULIRGs, will be compared with those of buried-AGN-dominated ULIRGs (buried AGN dominated sources are found almost exclusively in ULIRGs).
The HCN J=4-3 peak flux of NGC 1614 is measured to be 20 mJy, based on our ALMA Cycle 0 data (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a). We thus obtain a conservative lower limit of the HCN J=3-2 peak flux of 11 mJy, in the case of thermal excitation. The measured HCN J=4-3 peak flux is 1/10 of the expected value based on the conversion from IRAS-measured infrared flux to HCN J=1-0 flux peak, and on the assumption of thermal excitation. Thus, HCN J=4-3 emission is subthermally-excited in NGC 1614, and the HCN J=3-2 peak flux must be >11 mJy.
The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.5 hr observing time, we can achieve 2.0 mJy noise level for the 20 km/s velocity resolution. Even in the most pessimistic case (11 mJy), the HCN J=3-2 peak flux should be detected with >5 sigma.
HCO+ J=3-2 line is simultaneously observable with HCN J=3-2 line.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use three spectral windows in USB to cover HCN J=3-2, HCO+ J=3-2 + HCN v2=1f J=3-2, and HCO+ v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time. This is the reason for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

############################# # IRAS 08572+3915 HNC J=3-2 # #############################
Basic observing parameters: For our molecular line observations of all sources, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA) (C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6), to pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas emission at galaxy nuclei (<1 arc sec in size). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values. We set the detection significance of >5 for the peak flux of the target HCN molecular lines of all sources, in the 20 km/s velocity resolution spectra.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: While HCN J=3-2 and HCO+ J=3-2 lines are simultaneously observable with ALMA, we need separate observation of HNC J=3-2 line. To constrain the flux ratios among HCN/HCO+/HNC J=3-2 in IRAS 08572+3915, we set the same noise level (1.0 mJy) as employed for the HCN/HCO+ J=3-2 observation of IRAS 08572+3915, for the HNC observation. The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.7 hr observing time, we can achieve 1.0 mJy noise level for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use two spectral windows in USB to cover HNC J=3-2 and HNC v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time. Additional two spectral windows in LSB will be used to estimate the possible continuum spectral index and to better understand the physical origin of the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines. In fact, our ALMA Cycle 0 data show discernible flux difference of the continuum emission between USB and LSB (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c). These are the reasons for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

############################ # Superantennae HNC J=3-2 # ############################
Basic observing parameters: For our molecular line observations of all sources, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA) (C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6), to pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas emission at galaxy nuclei (<1 arc sec in size). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values. We set the detection significance of >5 for the peak flux of the target HCN molecular lines of all sources, in the 20 km/s velocity resolution spectra.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: To constrain the flux ratios among HCN/HCO+/HNC J=3-2 in Superantennae, we set the same noise level (1.0 mJy) as employed for the HCN/HCO+ J=3-2 observation of Superantennae, for the HNC observation. The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.6 hr observing time, we can achieve 1.0 mJy noise level for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use two spectral windows in USB to cover HNC J=3-2 and HNC v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time. Additional two spectral windows in LSB will be used to better understand the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines. In fact, our ALMA Cycle 0 data show discernible flux difference of the continuum emission between USB and LSB (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c). These are the reasons for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

############################# # IRAS 12112+0305 HNC J=3-2 # #############################
Basic observing parameters: For our molecular line observations of all sources, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA) (C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6), to pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas emission at galaxy nuclei (<1 arc sec in size). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values. We set the detection significance of >5 for the peak flux of the target HCN molecular lines of all sources, in the 20 km/s velocity resolution spectra.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: To constrain the flux ratios among HCN/HCO+/HNC J=3-2 in IRAS 12112+0305, we set the same noise level (1.5 mJy) as employed for the HCN/HCO+ J=3-2 observation of IRAS 12112+0305, for the HNC observation. The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.5 hr observing time, we can achieve 1.5 mJy noise level for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use two spectral windows in USB to cover HNC J=3-2 and HNC v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time. Additional two spectral windows in LSB will be used to better understand the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines. In fact, our ALMA Cycle 0 data show discernible flux difference of the continuum emission between USB and LSB (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c). These are the reasons for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

############################# # IRAS 22491-1808 HNC J=3-2 # #############################
Basic observing parameters: For our molecular line observations of all sources, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA) (C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6), to pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas emission at galaxy nuclei (<1 arc sec in size). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values. We set the detection significance of >5 for the peak flux of the target HCN molecular lines of all sources, in the 20 km/s velocity resolution spectra.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: To constrain the flux ratios among HCN/HCO+/HNC J=3-2 in IRAS 22491-1808, we set the same noise level (2.0 mJy) as employed for the HCN/HCO+ J=3-2 observation of IRAS 22491-1808, for the HNC observation. The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.5 hr observing time, we can achieve 2.0 mJy noise level for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use two spectral windows in USB to cover HNC J=3-2 and HNC v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time. Additional two spectral windows in LSB will be used to better understand the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines. In fact, our ALMA Cycle 0 data show discernible flux difference of the continuum emission between USB and LSB (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c). These are the reasons for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

###################### # NGC 1614 HNC J=3-2 # ######################
Basic observing parameters: For our molecular line observations of all sources, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA) (C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6), to pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas emission at galaxy nuclei (<1 arc sec in size). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values. We set the detection significance of >5 for the peak flux of the target HCN molecular lines of all sources, in the 20 km/s velocity resolution spectra.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: To constrain the flux ratios among HCN/HCO+/HNC J=3-2 in NGC 1614, we set the same noise level (2.0 mJy) as employed for the HCN/HCO+ J=3-2 observation of NGC 1614, for the HNC observation. The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.5 hr observing time, we can achieve 2.0 mJy noise level for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use two spectral windows in USB to cover HNC J=3-2 and HNC v2=1f J=3-2 lines at the same time. Additional two spectral windows in LSB will be used to better understand the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines. In fact, our ALMA Cycle 0 data show discernible flux difference of the continuum emission between USB and LSB (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c). These are the reasons for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

################################# # Superantennae HCN/HCO+ J=4-3 # #################################
Basic observing parameters: For our molecular line observations of all sources, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA) (C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6), to pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas emission at galaxy nuclei (<1 arc sec in size). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values. We set the detection significance of >5 for the peak flux of the target HCN molecular lines of all sources, in the 20 km/s velocity resolution spectra.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: We need HCN/HCO+/HNC J=4-3 line data for Superantennae. The expected HCN J=4-3 peak flux from (1) the HCN J=1-0 peak flux converted from the IRAS-measured infrared flux and (2) assumption for thermal excitation, is 55 mJy. We also consider the case that HCN J=4-3 peak flux is only 1/5 of the expected value for thermal excitation. We adopt 11-55 mJy as the HCN J=4-3 peak flux of Superantennae.
The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.5 hr observing time, we can achieve 2.0 mJy noise level for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
HCO+ J=4-3 line is simultaneously observable with HCN J=4-3.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use two spectral windows in LSB to cover HCN J=4-3 and HCO+ J=4-3 lines at the same time. Additional two spectral windows in USB will be used to better understand the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines. In fact, our ALMA Cycle 0 data show discernible flux difference of the continuum emission between USB and LSB (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c). These are the reasons for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.
For Superantennae, we will observe HCN and HCO+ J=4-3 lines in LSB (not USB), to obtain both USB and LSB data at the frequencies of good Earth's atmospheric transmission.

################################## # IRAS 12112+0305 HCN/HCO+ J=4-3 # ##################################
Basic observing parameters: For our molecular line observations of all sources, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA) (C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6), to pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas emission at galaxy nuclei (<1 arc sec in size). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values. We set the detection significance of >5 for the peak flux of the target HCN molecular lines of all sources, in the 20 km/s velocity resolution spectra.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: We need HCN/HCO+/HNC J=4-3 line data for IRAS 12112+0305. The expected HCN J=4-3 peak flux from (1) the HCN J=1-0 peak flux converted from the IRAS-measured infrared flux and (2) assumption for thermal excitation, is 70 mJy. We also consider the case that HCN J=4-3 peak flux is only 1/5 of the expected value for thermal excitation. We adopt 14-70 mJy as the HCN J=4-3 peak flux of IRAS 12112+0305.
The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.5 hr observing time, we can achieve 2.0 mJy noise level for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
HCO+ J=4-3 line is simultaneously observable with HCN J=4-3.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use two spectral windows in USB to cover HCN J=4-3 and HCO+ J=4-3 lines at the same time. Additional two spectral windows in LSB will be used to better understand the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines. In fact, our ALMA Cycle 0 data show discernible flux difference of the continuum emission between USB and LSB (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c). These are the reasons for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

############################# # IRAS 08572+3915 HNC J=4-3 # #############################
Basic observing parameters: For our molecular line observations of all sources, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA) (C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6), to pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas emission at galaxy nuclei (<1 arc sec in size). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values. We set the detection significance of >5 for the peak flux of the target HCN molecular lines of all sources, in the 20 km/s velocity resolution spectra.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: Although HNC J=4-3 observation of IRAS 08572+3915 was conducted in our ALMA Cycle 0 program (2011.0.00020.S), data were not provided to us because they did not pass the most basic quality checks. So we need HNC J=4-3 line data for IRAS 08572+3915.
The achieved 1 sigma noise level for our ALMA Cycle 0 HCN/HCO+ J=4-3 data of IRAS 08572+3915 is 2.0 mJy for 20 km/s velocity resolution. The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.5 hr observing time, we can achieve 2.0 mJy noise level for HNC J=4-3 data, for the 20 km/s velocity resolution.
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use two spectral windows in USB to cover HNC J=4-3 and HNC v2=1f J=4-3 lines at the same time. Additional two spectral windows in LSB will be used to better understand the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines. In fact, our ALMA Cycle 0 data show discernible flux difference of the continuum emission between USB and LSB (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c). These are the reasons for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

########################### # Superantennae HNC J=4-3 # ###########################
Basic observing parameters: For our molecular line observations of all sources, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA) (C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6), to pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas emission at galaxy nuclei (<1 arc sec in size). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values. We set the detection significance of >5 for the peak flux of the target HCN molecular lines of all sources, in the 20 km/s velocity resolution spectra.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.5 hr observing time, we can achieve 2.0 mJy noise level for the 20 km/s velocity resolution (which is the same noise level as the HCN/HCO+ J=4-3 data of Superantennae).
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use two spectral windows in LSB to cover HNC J=4-3 and HNC v2=1f J=4-3 lines at the same time. Additional two spectral windows in USB will be used to better understand the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines. In fact, our ALMA Cycle 0 data show discernible flux difference of the continuum emission between USB and LSB (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c). These are the reasons for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.
For Superantennae, we will observe HNC J=4-3 line in LSB (not USB), to obtain both USB and LSB data at the frequencies of good Earth's atmospheric transmission.

############################# # IRAS 12112+0305 HNC J=4-3 # #############################
Basic observing parameters: For our molecular line observations of all sources, we request 0.6 arcsec spatial resolution (without ACA) (C34-2,3,4,5,6,7 for band 7, and C34-3,4,5,6,7 for band 6), to pinpoint AGN affected molecular gas emission at galaxy nuclei (<1 arc sec in size). We will use the widest band mode of ALMA (1.875 GHz), and adopt a 20 km/s velocity resolution. When we calculate required observing times, we always adopt the default precipitable water vapor values. We set the detection significance of >5 for the peak flux of the target HCN molecular lines of all sources, in the 20 km/s velocity resolution spectra.
Imaging: single pointing (nuclear compact source)
Calibration and bandpass accuracy: default
Scheduling/time constraints: none
Sensitivity: The ALMA sensitivity calculator shows that with 0.5 hr observing time, we can achieve 2.0 mJy noise level for the 20 km/s velocity resolution (which is the same noise level as the HCN/HCO+ J=4-3 data of IRAS 12112+0305).
Correlator setup and data rate: We will use two spectral windows in USB to cover HNC J=4-3 and HNC v2=1f J=4-3 lines at the same time. Additional two spectral windows in LSB will be used to better understand the continuum emission, after correcting for serendipitously detected emission lines. In fact, our ALMA Cycle 0 data show discernible flux difference of the continuum emission between USB and LSB (Imanishi & Nakanishi 2013a,b,c). These are the reasons for slightly higher data rate than 6 MB/s, but the data rate is well below 60 MB/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose molecular line observations of nearby infrared luminous dust/gas-rich galaxies for which the relative energetic importance of AGN and starburst has been quantitatively well-calibrated through previous infrared spectroscopy. Using different feedback from AGNs and starbursts to the surrounding molecular gas, we aim to establish a reliable method to scrutinize optically elusive buried AGNs in dusty galaxies, based on bright molecular line flux ratios at the dust-extinction-free (sub)millimeter wavelength. Our pre-ALMA and ALMA Cycle 0 observations have shown that enhanced HCN emission is empirically an excellent AGN indicator, but its physical origin is unclear. We propose ALMA Cycle 2 observations of these well-calibrated galaxies, at multiple transition lines of HCN/HCO+/HNC, in order to clarify the physical origin (i.e., an HCN abundance enhancement or excitation effect). Our (sub)millimeter energy diagnostic method using bright molecular lines, once established, will have a large potential to understand the interplay between suparmassive blackholes and star-formation in distant infrared luminous galaxies, which are known to dominate the cosmic dust-obscured activity.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This is an extension of our accepted ALMA Cycle 0 program (2011.0.00020.S) (PI = M. Imanishi).
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Optical and Infrared Astronomy, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
School of Physical Sciences, Graduate University for Advanced Studies
